Articles.Content: Well after alot of hard work trying to land, I finally got the Mun Rover 1 onto the moon! yay for me!
Ha! Good! try sending a bigger one!
Congratulations! Looks like a toaster with wheels, and a nice center of balance too

Yeah, that thing isn't going to flip over, wish I could say the same about a few of my designs...

Anyways, congratulations!

Yeah, that thing isn't going to flip over, wish I could say the same about a few of my designs...

Anyways, congratulations!

Flipped over 5 times now Good thing there's quicksave!
So that's where my K-box 720 went! TO THE MOON! I mean... MÃƒÅ“N!!

Ha! Good! try sending a bigger one!

Why, unless its a manned mission or you want to see how fast you can go or similar its just as well to keep it small.

However it look like you forgotten the solar panels?

However it look like you forgotten the solar panels?

The solar panels are on the top-rear of the rover
The antennas looks like RemoteTech ones. Are you using a RemoteTech probe or just a stock one?

The antennas looks like RemoteTech ones. Are you using a RemoteTech probe or just a stock one?

Remote tech antennas, yup. But the Probe/command center (err...) is actually the body of the rover, and the body of the rover is from rovemate.

Flipped over 5 times now Good thing there's quicksave!

Build your rovers with a self righting mechanism (haven't any of you watched Robot Wars in the 90's?) like in these pictures:

Mine are built from stock landing legs parts - mounted on the roof of the vehicle. To get mine to work I had to rightclick them and operate them selectively one at a time instead of using the "G" key to do all at once, because I had to alternate using the left and right pair rather than toggling them together all at once, but the design did work.

Build your rovers with a self righting mechanism (haven't any of you watched Robot Wars in the 90's?) like in these pictures:

Mine are built from stock landing legs parts - mounted on the roof of the vehicle. To get mine to work I had to rightclick them and operate them selectively one at a time instead of using the "G" key to do all at once, because I had to alternate using the left and right pair rather than toggling them together all at once, but the design did work.

Nice design! It's true, "Necessity is the mother of invention"!

Heres my rover, I had it land on the mun first as a test that it can work inthe dark for a long time and could land with and without a parachute. It blew up on the mun....I had a lander land ontop of it >.< Must of cooked it!
